title: Missing memory corruption protection on Windows release built

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,
we have noticed that the Windows Desktop Client doesn't enable the protections ASLR and DEP (and others). These protections are per-default enabled since approximately 10 years in Visual Studio and are very important because they make exploitation a lot harder (or even make some vulnerabilities not exploitable).

Please note: The Nextcloud code was updated on 4 September 2017 to enable ASLR and DEP. Here is the commit:
https://github.com/nextcloud/desktop/commit/6f270a364895d7f1f0a424c8347cd2913971cca4#diff-95e351a3805a1dafa85bf20b81d086e6

However, the current NextCloud Client (version 2.3.3.1) from 20 November 2017 from revision 57bc79 still doesn't have ASLR and DEP enabled. Here is the revision (where ASLR/DEP is also not enabled in the CMakeLists.txt file:
https://github.com/owncloud/client/commit/57bc7918d7b0650c116f3512787f7677d4e5ab17


Attached is a detailed description of the issue.

## Impact

An attacker has to find an additional vulnerability to exploit the missing memory corruption protections. For example, an attacker can search for a buffer overflow, use-after-free, type-confusion, ... vulnerability in the network communication and send a malicious payload / file from his Nextcloud server.
This vulnerability must not exist in the Nextcloud source code, for example, vulnerabilities in QT or other third-party libraries can also be used. For example, the current Nextcloud version uses QT 5.6.2 which was released on 11-Oct-2016. On 19-Oct-2016 a heap buffer overflow was found in QJsonDocument: https://www.peter.hartmann.tk/single-post/2016/11/29/Fuzzing-Qt-with-libFuzzer
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,
we have noticed that the Windows Desktop Client doesn't enable the protections ASLR and DEP (and others). These protections are per-default enabled since approximately 10 years in Visual Studio and are very important because they make exploitation a lot harder (or even make some vulnerabilities not exploitable).

Please note: The Nextcloud code was updated on 4 September 2017 to enable ASLR and DEP. Here is the commit:
https://github.com/nextcloud/desktop/commit/6f270a364895d7f1f0a424c8347cd2913971cca4#diff-95e351a3805a1dafa85bf20b81d086e6

However, the current NextCloud Client (version 2.3.3.1) from 20 November 2017 from revision 57bc79 still doesn't have ASLR and DEP enabled. Here is the revision (where ASLR/DEP is also not enabled in the CMakeLists.txt file:
https://github.com/owncloud/client/commit/57bc7918d7b0650c116f3512787f7677d4e5ab17

Attached is a detailed description of the issue.

Impact

An attacker has to find an additional vulnerability to exploit the missing memory corruption protections. For example, an attacker can search for a buffer overflow, use-after-free, type-confusion, ... vulnerability in the network communication and send a malicious payload / file from his Nextcloud server.
This vulnerability must not exist in the Nextcloud source code, for example, vulnerabilities in QT or other third-party libraries can also be used. For example, the current Nextcloud version uses QT 5.6.2 which was released on 11-Oct-2016. On 19-Oct-2016 a heap buffer overflow was found in QJsonDocument: https://www.peter.hartmann.tk/single-post/2016/11/29/Fuzzing-Qt-with-libFuzzer

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.

activities.message:
Hi @secconsult,

Our previous builds (2.3.x) were done using crosscompiling with MinGW.
Our next builds will be build using the Visual Studio compiler. 

Could i ask you to validate if the builds at https://download.nextcloud.com/desktop/daily/Windows/ are correct?

Cheers,
--Roeland
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @secconsult,

Our previous builds (2.3.x) were done using crosscompiling with MinGW.
Our next builds will be build using the Visual Studio compiler.

Could i ask you to validate if the builds at https://download.nextcloud.com/desktop/daily/Windows/ are correct?

Cheers,
--Roeland

activities.message:
thanks for getting back to us! We took a short look already and ASLR and DEP are activated now in those versions!

But we also want to check the other flags as well and we will get back to you later on this.
activities.markdown_message:
thanks for getting back to us! We took a short look already and ASLR and DEP are activated now in those versions!

But we also want to check the other flags as well and we will get back to you later on this.

activities.message:
Tested package: "Nextcloud-2.5.0.0-Debug-20180711.exe"


ASLR & DEP & GS: Is enabled in the new build

 
/safeSEH:

Since this is a 64-bit build (and /SafeSEH is only required in 32-bit builds) this can't be verified.

 
CFG:

Is not enabled. This can be verified with the "Get-ProcessMitigation -Name nextcloud.exe -runningprocesses" command inside PowerShell.

More information on Control Flow Guard can be found here:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/secbp/control-flow-guard


When are the next public (non-beta/debug) releases planned?
activities.markdown_message:
Tested package: "Nextcloud-2.5.0.0-Debug-20180711.exe"

ASLR & DEP & GS: Is enabled in the new build

/safeSEH:

Since this is a 64-bit build (and /SafeSEH is only required in 32-bit builds) this can't be verified.

CFG:

Is not enabled. This can be verified with the "Get-ProcessMitigation -Name nextcloud.exe -runningprocesses" command inside PowerShell.

More information on Control Flow Guard can be found here:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/secbp/control-flow-guard

When are the next public (non-beta/debug) releases planned?

activities.message: is there still work going on here?

activities.message: Yes, we are still looking in the CFG issue.
activities.markdown_message: Yes, we are still looking in the CFG issue.

activities.message:
Congratulations! We have determined this to be eligible for a reward of $50.

Thanks a lot for making the internet a safer place and keep hacking. Please keep in mind that we didn't patch the vulnerability yet, so please do not share this information with any third-parties.

activities.message: thank you! we are not planning to release a security advisory on this issue, nevertheless in order to make nextcloud more secure it should be implemented earlier than later ;)
activities.markdown_message: thank you! we are not planning to release a security advisory on this issue, nevertheless in order to make nextcloud more secure it should be implemented earlier than later ;)

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for your report again. This has been resolved for the upcoming 2.7 releases and we're preparing the advisories.

Please let us know how you'd like to be credited in our official advisory. We require the following information:

- Name / Pseudonym
- Email address (optional)
- Website (optional)
- Company (optional)

additional_data.old_title: Missing all Memory Corruption Protections (ASLR/DEP/GS/SafeSEH/CFG/CIG/ACG) on Windows release built
